ARABIC: لِيَكْفُرُوا۟ بِمَآ ءَاتَيْنَٰهُمْ فَتَمَتَّعُوا۟ فَسَوْفَ تَعْلَمُونَ

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: to show ingratitude for what We have given them. 'Enjoy yourselves - you will soon know.'
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: So as to deny what We have given them. Please yourselves for a time; you will come to know soon.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: so that they may show ingratitude to Us for the favours We had bestowed upon them. So, enjoy yourselves a while; but then you shall soon come to know.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: because of their ingratitude for what We have given them. Let them enjoy themselves, but they will soon know (the consequences of their deeds).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: In order to be ungrateful for Our bestowal; “Therefore enjoy”; you will soon come to know.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: So as to be ungrateful for the graces which We have bestowed on them. Then enjoy; but you will come to know.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: So as to be ungrateful for what We have given them; but enjoy yourselves (for a while), for you shall soon come to know.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: that they may be ungrateful for what We have given them. 'Take your enjoyment; certainly you will soon know.'
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: So as to disbelieve in that which We have given them. (Unto such it is said): Enjoy yourselves awhile, but ye will come to know.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: and are ungrateful for what We have given them. So enjoy yourselves for a while, but soon you will come to know.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: So that they may be ungrateful for that which We have vouchsafed to them. So enjoy awhile; presently ye shall come to know.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: being ungrateful toward what We have given them. So let them enjoy. Soon they will know!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: (As if) to show their ingratitude for the (favours) We have bestowed on them! Then enjoy (your brief day); but soon will ye know (your folly).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: So as to be ungrateful for the graces which We have bestowed on them. Then enjoy (your short life); but you will come to know.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: disbelieving in what We have given them. Enjoy, but you shall soon know.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: To show ingratitude for what We have given them. Indulge yourselves—you will surely know.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: So that they will deny what We have granted them. Then enjoy yourselves, for you are going to know.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [30:34] Let them be ungrateful for what We have given them (this is [an imperative] meant as a threat). ‘So take   your enjoyment. Soon you will know’, the consequences of your enjoyment (there is a shift away from the third person address to the second).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (So as to disbelieve in that which We have given them) of blessings ((Unto such it is said): Enjoy yourselves awhile) live, O people of Mecca, in the life of this world, (but ye will come to know) what will be done with you in the Hereafter.
